Flamingo parents produce 'crop milk' in their throats - a special liquid baby food they use to feed newborn chicks before transitioning to regurgitated regular food.
A banana is a berry, but a strawberry is not - botanically, berries are fruits produced from a single ovary with seeds embedded in the flesh.
Continental tectonic plates drift at the same speed fingernails grow - up to 20 millimeters per year.
Reindeer eyes change color through the seasons - they're gold during summer and blue in winter.
Space has a distinct smell - astronauts describe it as a bouquet of diesel fumes, gunpowder, and barbecue, mostly produced by dying stars.
Russian cosmonauts used to pack a shotgun in case they landed in Siberia - for protection against bears.
Goats have rectangular pupils - the unusual shape gives them a wider field of view to help them stay aware of their surroundings and predators.
Army ants can break from their scent trails and march in circles - if enough ants join, they form massive 'death spirals' where they march until exhaustion.
Apollo 17 astronaut Harrison Schmitt was allergic to moon dust - it caused the inside of his nose to swell and affected his throat.
Bloodcurdling is more than an expression - research shows watching horror movies can increase certain clotting proteins in our bloodstreams.
Volvo gave away the patent for the three-point seat belt in 1962 for free - specifically to save lives rather than profit from the invention.
The tin can was patented in 1810 by Peter Durand, but the can opener wasn't patented until 1858 - for 48 years, people used chisels and hammers to open cans.
Marie Curie remains the only person to earn Nobel Prizes in two different sciences (Physics in 1903 and Chemistry in 1911).
Dogs are capable of understanding up to 250 words and gestures - the average dog is as intelligent as a 2-year-old child.
Bubbles in a bath keep water warmer longer by forming an insulating layer on the surface that reduces heat loss to the air.
The manchineel tree is called the 'tree of death' - touching it can leave chemical burns on your skin, its fruit is toxic, and smoke from burning its bark can cause blindness.
China owns all giant pandas in the world and rents them to zoos for about $1 million per year.
Bones found at Seymour Island indicate that 37-40 million years ago, penguins stood 6 feet tall and weighed 250 pounds - today's Emperor penguins are about 4 feet tall and 100 pounds.
There is a medical term for ice cream headaches - sphenopalatine ganglioneuralgia, caused by rapid cooling of the capillaries in the sinuses.
In Switzerland, it's illegal to own only one guinea pig because they're social creatures - the law aims to prevent guinea pigs from getting lonely.
Foreign Accent Syndrome is a rare side effect of brain trauma where patients speak their native language in a foreign accent.
Chihuahuas have the biggest brains relative to their body size in the dog world, making them very easy to train.
A double rainbow occurs when sunlight is reflected twice inside a raindrop - the colors of the secondary rainbow appear in reverse order.
When elephants are upset, they will comfort each other by stroking loved ones with their trunks and emitting small chirps - young elephants also suck their trunks for comfort.
A solar eclipse helped end a six-year war in 585 BCE - when the sky suddenly darkened during a battle between the Lydians and the Medes, soldiers took it as a sign to cease fighting.
The annual number of worldwide shark bites is 10 times less than the number of people bitten by other people in New York alone.
Kea parrots are the first known non-mammal species to communicate with infectious laughter - they warble together when in a good mood.
Truman Show Delusion is a real mental condition where patients believe they are the star of an imaginary reality show - the term was coined by two psychiatrists in 2008.
Blood donors in Sweden receive a thank-you text message when their blood is actually used to help a patient.
The ampersand symbol (&) is formed from the letters in 'et', the Latin word for 'and'.
An avocado never ripens on the tree - farmers can use trees as storage and keep avocados fresh for up to seven months.
In traditional vampire folklore, bloodsuckers have arithmomania - a compulsion to count - which is why Count von Count on Sesame Street loves numbers.
The WAFFLE House Index is informally used by FEMA to gauge storm severity - due to the restaurant's legendary reputation for staying open in extreme weather.
The 100 folds in a chef's toque (tall white hat) are said to represent 100 ways to cook an egg.
Guinness once estimated that 93,000 liters of beer are lost in facial hair each year in the UK alone.
Scientists at Purdue built a licking machine to solve the Tootsie Pop mystery - on average, it takes 364 licks to get to the center.
The Lost City Hydrothermal Field produces up to 100 times more hydrogen and methane than black smoker vents, which rely on magma heat.
Scientists recovered a record-breaking 1,268-meter-long core sample from the Lost City Hydrothermal Field in 2024 - it may provide evidence of how life first emerged on Earth.
The Lost City ecosystem doesn't depend on sunlight or magma heat - hydrocarbons produced by chemical reactions between the mantle and seawater feed microbial communities without oxygen.
The most sophisticated supercomputer in 2010 performed 83 times slower than a cat's brain at processing information.
Cats have a gene called Taqpep that determines whether they have stripes, spots, or blotched patterns - blotched cats have mutations on both copies of the gene.
Cats' short-term memory for physical movement (stepping over obstacles) lasts about 10 minutes, but their visual-only memory lasts just a few seconds.

Cats are susceptible to more than 250 hereditary disorders similar to human diseases, including retinitis pigmentosa, Feline Immunodeficiency Virus (related to HIV), and their own form of Alzheimer's Disease.
Disrupting a cat's routine can make even healthy cats exhibit symptoms of illness, including vomiting, decreased appetite, and going to the bathroom outside the litter box.
Google's artificial 'Brain' computer (with 16,000 processors that learns from the Internet) independently developed a strong preference for watching cat videos.
Cats subject to 'whisker stress' may prefer licking water off their paws because they don't like pressure on their whiskers while drinking from deep bowls.

Male cats have barbed penises with 120+ backward-pointing spines - neutering early prevents spine development. Scientists theorize the spines may encourage ovulation or keep the penis in place during mating.
Ravens can hold grudges for weeks against other ravens who treated them unfairly, but will respond in a friendly way to birds they liked for at least three years.
Ravens make toys - a rare animal behavior - using sticks, pinecones, golf balls, or rocks to play with each other or by themselves.
Ravens in Alaska and Canada have been observed using snow-covered roofs as slides, and in Maine they've been seen rolling down snowy hills for fun.
Ravens show empathy - when a raven's friend loses a fight, they console the losing bird.

Ravens have pushed rocks on people to keep them from climbing to their nests, played dead beside beaver carcasses to scare other ravens away, and stolen packaged meats from Costco customers' shopping carts.

Trained elephants in Indonesia help fight forest fires - carrying water pumps and hoses, 23 elephants from a conservation center helped patrol land and prevent new fires during the 2015 East Sumatra fires.
In 2015, scientists captured the first video of an elephant yawning - until then, it was only speculation that elephants yawned.
At Zambia's Mfuwe Lodge, families of elephants walk through the hotel lobby every October-December to eat wild mango from a courtyard tree.
Elephants are not actually scared of mice - they have poor vision and can get startled when anything suddenly scurries by, but mice themselves don't frighten them.
YouTube's first-ever video, uploaded April 23, 2005, featured elephants at a zoo - co-founder Jawed Karim stood in front of them discussing their 'cool' long trunks.
King Mongkut of Siam offered to send elephants to the U.S. to breed in forests in 1861, but Lincoln's Secretary of State declined because America already used steam power.
In 1912, Barnum & Bailey trained elephants to play baseball - they used the image on posters to sell circus tickets.
Berlin zoos feed unsold Christmas trees to their elephants each January - the trees are certified pesticide-free.
The word 'penguin' originally referred to great auks (Pinguinus impennis), a now-extinct species in the Northern Hemisphere - Southern explorers used the name for similar-looking birds.
Gentoo penguins are the fastest penguin species, reaching swimming speeds up to 22 mph.
Wild penguins show no particular fear of human tourists because they aren't used to danger from animals on solid ground.
For some penguin species, pudgy males with enough fat to survive weeks without eating are most desirable mates - males incubate eggs while females hunt for weeks.
Penguins stay warm not through blubber like other sea mammals, but by trapping a layer of warm air next to their skin with their feathers.
Despite lacking visible ears, penguins have excellent hearing and rely on distinct calls to identify their mates among thousands of birds in crowded breeding grounds.
Mercury's surface has mysterious bright streaks that appear to be caused by very recent geological activity - the 'dead' planet may still be geologically active after 4.5 billion years.

Scientists have catalogued 402 bright streaks (lineae) on Mercury's surface that tend to cluster on sun-facing slopes of craters - they may still be forming today through the flow of heat and volatile materials like sulfur from below.

Following 150 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous exercise per week for 12 months can make your brain look biologically 0.6 years younger on MRI scans - the control group showed brains 0.35 years older than chronological age.

Great white sharks undergo a major dental transformation at around 3 meters in body length - their slim teeth with small side cusplets for gripping fish are replaced by broader, serrated teeth for slicing through marine mammal flesh and bone.

Great white shark teeth are continuously replaced like a conveyor belt, roughly every few weeks - the design changes to match their diet as they grow from fish-eating juveniles to marine-mammal-hunting adults.
The first two teeth on either side of a great white's jaw are significantly thicker at the base - these are the primary 'impact' teeth that take the force of the initial bite.
Dolphins sleep with one hemisphere of their brain at a time for 15-20 minutes - this allows them to continue swimming, breathing, and watching for predators 24/7.
Each dolphin has its own unique signature whistle that scientists believe they use for life - female dolphins may even teach their calves their whistles before birth.
Dolphins may remember other dolphins' signature whistles after decades apart - they use these personal whistles to call out to one another.
A dolphin's skin can be completely sloughed off and replaced with new skin cells as often as every two hours - this keeps their skin smooth and reduces drag while swimming.
The U.S. Navy trains dolphins to find enemy swimmers, locate underwater mines, and guard nuclear arsenals - utilizing their intelligence, speed, and echolocation abilities.
Dolphins have multiple stomach chambers - one is devoted to digestion while others store food before it's digested, since dolphins swallow prey whole without chewing.
Dolphin calves are born tail first rather than head first - this prevents drowning during the birthing process.
Dolphins segregate themselves into friend groups rather than spending equal time with all nearby dolphins - scientists discovered this after tracking 200 bottlenose dolphins for six years.
The Orca (Killer Whale) is actually a dolphin species - at 30 feet long, it's 10 times longer than the smallest dolphins.
Dolphin pods can merge to form 'superpods' of more than 1,000 dolphins - these typically form temporarily in areas with plentiful food.
Female dolphins produce burst-pulse sounds to reprimand their offspring for bad behavior - similar to how human parents scold children.
The oldest dolphin in captivity was Nellie, a bottlenose dolphin who lived to age 61 in a Florida marine park - most wild dolphins live only a few decades.
Great white sharks have different tooth shapes across their jaw - the first six teeth are triangular for cutting, while teeth further back become blade-like for tearing flesh.
Sharks are older than trees - their ancestors evolved approximately 450 million years ago, while trees appeared around 350 million years ago.
A cow was documented using tools to scratch herself in 2024 - the first scientific recording of tool use in bovines.
Octopuses are masters of invisibility through rapid camouflage - scientists are studying their techniques to develop new technologies.
Polar bears in some populations are getting fatter, surprising scientists who expected climate change to reduce their food sources.
Truffle-hunting dogs are advancing scientific understanding of fungi by locating previously unknown species underground.
Invasive species are disrupting the mating rituals of native species - sometimes preventing successful reproduction through interference.
Seahorses have a hidden kingdom - Sweetings Pond in the Bahamas contains a unique population that scientists are working to understand and protect.
Humpback whale songs helped save them from extinction - recordings of their haunting calls in the 1970s sparked the 'Save the Whales' movement.
Twin mountain gorillas are extremely rare - when twins were born in Virunga National Park in 2024, researchers called it 'kind of miraculous'.
Some tarantulas living in remote caves can grow as large as dinner plates.
PFAS 'forever chemicals' have been linked to multiple sclerosis in a concerning new study published in 2026.
A common sleeping pill may reduce the buildup of Alzheimer's proteins in the brain, according to a 2026 study.
Sleep loss physically damages brain cells - but this damage can be countered with proper sleep recovery.
Cancer may emit protective signals that guard the brain against Alzheimer's disease - explaining a puzzling inverse relationship between the conditions.
Scientists have developed a breakthrough method that could double rare earth element extraction from ores.
U.S. life expectancy hit a record high in 2024 and could still be climbing.
A keto diet for weight loss may have a serious downside - a mouse study found concerning effects that warrant further research.
A cheap daily vitamin D supplement may have surprising health benefits specifically for women.
Being a 'night owl' is linked to higher heart attack and stroke risk according to a major study.
AI detected a mysterious hidden detail in a famous Raphael masterpiece that human experts had missed.
Scientists have identified specific epigenetic switches that can slow the production of fat cells.
Like human babies, Chihuahuas have a soft spot on their heads called a molera - but unlike babies, they may keep this soft spot their entire lives.
The ancient Chihuahua breed (Techichi) was kept as lap dogs by Toltecs in Mexico as early as the 9th century CE - the breed later shrunk after being crossed with smaller hairless dogs from Asia.
In 2014, a feral pack of Chihuahuas terrorized an Arizona town - they would form large groups, harass residents, and sometimes team up with larger dogs.
Studies show Chihuahuas are one of the most aggressive dog breeds toward both humans and other dogs despite their tiny size - they compensate with fierceness.
The smallest dog in the world is a Chihuahua named Milly who was small enough to fit in a teaspoon when she was born.

The sight of a dead crow attracts a mob of 100+ live crows for what scientists call a 'funeral' - but the birds almost never touch the dead one and seem hesitant to revisit spots where they encountered deceased crows.
Crows in Japan steal fiber-optic cables for nesting material and cause about 100 power failures per year - between 2006-2008, they stole nearly 1,400 fiber-optic cables from Tokyo power providers.
The New Caledonian crow's brain weighs 0.26 ounces but accounts for 2.7% of its overall weight - proportionately much larger than a human's 3-pound brain which is only 1.9% of body weight.
Crows have regional dialects in their calls, and when a crow joins a new flock, it learns the flock's dialect by mimicking the calls of dominant flock members.
Carrion crows in Japan have learned to use traffic lights - they wait for red to place walnuts on roads for cars to crush, then wait for the next red light to safely retrieve the opened nuts.
Crows can recognize human faces and hold grudges across generations - in experiments, crows who were never captured still scolded and dive-bombed researchers wearing a 'threatening' mask years later.
The New Caledonian crow is one of only two species that can craft hooks in the wild (the other is Homo sapiens) - they bend pliable twigs into J-shapes to extract insects from tight crevices.

Unlike virtually all other birds, the New Caledonian crow has a bill that doesn't curve downward - scientists believe it evolved this way to help grasp tools more easily and see what the tool is doing.
80% of American crow nests have 'helpers' - juvenile crows that defend their parents' nest, bring food, or feed younger siblings, sometimes providing aid for over half a decade.
Crows and ravens understand delayed gratification - they will patiently wait for a better food reward rather than eating immediately, but only if the second option is genuinely superior.
A 2020 study found crows can perceive sensory input consciously, despite lacking a cerebral cortex - suggesting consciousness may have evolved multiple times in different brain structures.
Goats' horizontal rectangular pupils give them a sharp panoramic view that lets them see nearly all around themselves - this helps them detect predators from various directions.
Goats' eyes rotate to keep their horizontal pupils aligned with the ground whether their heads are upright or face-down while grazing.
Pupil shape reveals an animal's role in the food chain - predators that ambush prey tend to have vertical slit pupils, while herbivores that are prey usually have horizontal pupils.
Vertical slit pupils help small ambush predators like cats and snakes judge distance for pouncing, while bigger cats and wolves have round pupils because they need to chase down prey.
Beyond round, horizontal, and vertical pupils, some animals have w-shaped, crescent-shaped, or even heart-shaped pupils - cuttlefish have w-shaped pupils.

Sleep consists of four distinct stages: three non-REM stages (N1, N2, N3) and one REM stage, which cycle throughout the night.
A typical sleep cycle lasts about 90 minutes, and most people go through 4-6 complete cycles per night.
Stage 1 (N1) sleep is the lightest stage and typically lasts only 1-7 minutes as you transition from wakefulness to sleep.
During Stage 2 (N2) sleep, body temperature drops, heart rate slows, and brief bursts of brain activity called sleep spindles occur.
Sleep spindles are periodic bursts of brain activity at 10-12 Hz that last 1-2 seconds and help resist being woken by external stimuli.
People spend approximately half their total sleep time in Stage 2 (N2) sleep.
Stage 3 (N3) is called deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, characterized by delta waves with frequencies of 1-4 Hz.
Deep sleep (N3) is critical for physical restoration, immune function, and memory consolidation.
You spend more time in deep sleep during the first half of the night, with N3 stages lasting 20-40 minutes in early cycles.
REM sleep typically begins about 90 minutes after falling asleep and gets progressively longer in later sleep cycles.
During REM sleep, brain activity increases to levels similar to being awake, while the body experiences temporary muscle paralysis (atonia).
REM sleep makes up approximately 25% of total sleep time in adults.
The first REM period of the night may last only a few minutes, while later REM periods can last up to an hour.
The amount of REM sleep decreases with age, from about 8 hours at birth to around 45 minutes at age 70.
Newborns can enter REM sleep immediately upon falling asleep, unlike adults who must progress through NREM stages first.
The thalamus is largely inactive during NREM sleep but becomes active during REM sleep, sending images and sensations that create dreams.
Beta waves (15-60 Hz) characterize the awake state, while theta waves appear during light sleep and delta waves dominate deep sleep.
Sleep architecture can be visualized in a hypnogram, a graph showing the progression through sleep stages over the night.
Alcohol can suppress REM sleep early in the night, followed by a REM rebound effect with prolonged REM periods later.
It is hardest to wake someone from Stage 3 (deep sleep), which is why it is considered the deepest stage of sleep.
The hypothalamus contains the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN), the master clock that controls circadian rhythms based on light exposure.
The pineal gland releases melatonin in response to darkness, helping regulate the sleep-wake cycle.
The brainstem (pons and medulla) sends signals during REM sleep to paralyze muscles, preventing us from acting out our dreams.
The amygdala, which processes emotions, becomes increasingly active during REM sleep.
Adenosine accumulates in the brain during wakefulness and promotes sleepiness; caffeine blocks adenosine receptors to counteract this effect.
The brain uses significantly less energy during non-REM sleep, allowing it to restore its supply of ATP.
While awake, the brain is responsible for about 20% of the body's total energy consumption.
Sleep plays a housekeeping role, removing toxins including amyloid proteins that build up in the brain during wakefulness.
GABA is a neurotransmitter associated with sleep, muscle relaxation, and sedation.
Orexin (also called hypocretin) is a brain chemical that helps regulate wakefulness; its deficiency causes narcolepsy type 1.
The human internal circadian clock operates on a cycle slightly longer than 24 hours (approximately 24.2 hours on average).
Light is the most powerful zeitgeber (time-keeper) that helps synchronize our internal clock with the 24-hour day.
Circadian rhythms regulate not just sleep but also body temperature, metabolism, hormone release, and immune function.
Core body temperature fluctuates with circadian rhythm, varying between approximately 36.2°C and 37.2°C throughout the day.
Melatonin levels peak at night and drop in the morning, helping to regulate the sleep-wake cycle.
Cortisol levels typically rise throughout the night, peak in the awakening hours, and diminish during the day.
During puberty, circadian rhythms shift later, causing teens to feel sleepy later at night and want to wake later in the morning.
People with damage to the suprachiasmatic nucleus sleep erratically throughout the day, unable to sync with light-dark cycles.
Most blind people maintain some ability to sense light, which helps them regulate their sleep-wake cycle.
Blue light from electronic devices suppresses melatonin production and can delay the sleep-wake cycle.
Shift workers often experience circadian rhythm disruption, leading to difficulty sleeping during the day and staying awake at night.
Jet lag occurs when the internal clock becomes misaligned with the local time zone after crossing multiple time zones.
Newborns don't have a fully established circadian rhythm; it begins developing around 2-4 months of age.
Chronotypes (morning larks vs. night owls) are partly determined by genetics affecting circadian rhythm timing.
In a free-running environment without time cues, humans continue to experience rhythmic sleep-wake patterns on a slightly longer than 24-hour cycle.
Around 1 in 5 U.S. adults sleep less than five hours a night, far below the recommended seven to nine hours.
Not sleeping can lower learning abilities by as much as 40%.
After 24 hours without sleep, a person may become anxious, irritable, and begin experiencing minor sensory distortions.
After 48 hours without sleep, complex hallucinations may develop, including seeing or hearing things that aren't there.
After 72 hours without sleep, a person may experience symptoms resembling psychosis, with intense hallucinations and delusions.
Chronic sleep deprivation increases the risk of high blood pressure, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, depression, and obesity.
Sleep deprivation symptoms typically resolve after a person gets adequate sleep again.
Microsleeps—brief episodes of sleep lasting only seconds—can occur involuntarily in sleep-deprived individuals.
Sleep debt shows evidence of being cumulative, though humans seem to reach maximum sleepiness about 30 hours after waking.
Animal studies show that prolonged sleep deprivation in rats leads to death within a few weeks despite adequate food.
Sleep deprivation tends to cause slower brain waves in the frontal cortex, shortened attention span, and impaired memory.
Even partial sleep deprivation can cause a significant reduction in emotional regulation and increased irritability.
Sleep deprivation can trigger migraines and tension headaches in people prone to them.
Newborns need 16-18 hours of sleep per day, which supports brain development and growth.
School-age children (6-12 years) need 9-12 hours of sleep per night.
Teenagers need about 8-10 hours of sleep per night for optimal health and performance.
Most adults need 7-9 hours of sleep per night, even into older age.
Older adults may have more difficulty getting enough sleep and are more likely to take medications that interfere with sleep.
Humans spend about two hours each night dreaming, though most dreams are not remembered.
Dreams can occur during any sleep stage but are most vivid and common during REM sleep.
Dreams during REM sleep tend to be more fantastical and bizarre, while non-REM dreams are more coherent and grounded.
Some people dream in color while others recall dreams only in black and white.
People who are blind from birth do not have visual dreams; their dreams involve sounds, touch, smell, and taste.
The most common emotion experienced in dreams is anxiety, according to dream content analysis studies.
Sexual dreams occur in no more than 10% of reported dreams and are more common in teenagers.
The visual imagery in dreams is believed to be produced by activation of the same brain structures that process visual perception while awake.
Dreams may serve functions including memory consolidation, emotional processing, and mental housekeeping.
The COVID-19 pandemic increased themes of fear, illness, and death in dreams by 2-4 times compared to pre-pandemic levels.
Dream interpretation was practiced by Babylonians as early as the third millennium BCE.
Calvin S. Hall collected over 50,000 dream reports between the 1940s and 1985 for scientific analysis.
About 55% of people have experienced a lucid dream at least once—realizing they are dreaming while still asleep.
In about one-third of lucid dreams, the dreamer can influence or control what happens during the dream.
Lucid dreaming generally occurs during REM sleep and is more likely in the second half of the sleep period.
The MILD technique (Mnemonic Induction of Lucid Dreams) involves creating an intention to recognize when you're dreaming before falling asleep.
The Wake Back To Bed (WBTB) technique involves waking after 5+ hours of sleep, staying awake briefly, then returning to sleep to induce lucid dreams.
Galantamine, a drug used to treat Alzheimer's disease, has been shown to effectively induce lucid dreams in research studies.
Researchers have achieved a 42% success rate in inducing lucid dreams using a combination of techniques including supplements and light stimulation.
Frequent lucid dreaming may decrease sleep quality or potentially trigger sleep paralysis in some people.
Memory consolidation—preserving key memories and discarding excess information—takes place during both NREM and REM sleep stages.
Sleep helps you process new information after you wake up and consolidates learning that occurred during the day.
The medial prefrontal cortex produces slow waves important for memory consolidation; this area deteriorates with age, affecting older adults' memory processing.
Children experience stronger memory consolidation after sleep compared to adults.
A 2010 Harvard study showed experimental evidence that dreams are correlated with improved learning.
REM sleep appears essential for creativity and making novel associations between concepts.
Emotional memories are processed during REM sleep, which may help people cope with difficult experiences.
Insomnia affects up to two-thirds of people occasionally, making it one of the most common sleep concerns.
Narcolepsy is characterized by the brain's inability to properly regulate sleep-wake cycles, causing extreme daytime sleepiness.
Narcolepsy type 1 involves cataplexy—sudden loss of muscle tone—and affects 20-67 people per 100,000 in the US.
In narcolepsy, REM sleep can begin within minutes of falling asleep, rather than the normal 90 minutes.
Up to 98% of people with narcolepsy type 1 carry a specific gene variation called DQB1*0602.
People with narcolepsy are 3-4 times more likely to be involved in car accidents due to sudden sleep episodes.
Sleep apnea affects an estimated 30 million adults in the United States.
Over 900 million people worldwide live with obstructive sleep apnea.
Severe sleep apnea involves more than 30 breathing cessation events per hour of sleep.
Sleep apnea has been linked to memory problems, particularly difficulty forming autobiographical memories.
Central sleep apnea occurs when the brain fails to properly signal the muscles that control breathing during sleep.
Parasomnias are undesirable experiences that happen while sleeping, falling asleep, or waking up—most people experience them at some point.
NREM parasomnias are called 'disorders of arousal' because people partially wake up but may have no memory of the event.
REM-related parasomnias tend to occur in the final hours of sleep and people can usually remember these episodes.
Sleep deprivation can alter sleep stages and increase the likelihood of experiencing parasomnias.
Sleep paralysis affects about 20% of people at some point in their lives.
Sleep paralysis episodes typically last from a few seconds to about 20 minutes, with an average of around 6 minutes.
About 75% of sleep paralysis episodes involve hallucinations, including sensing a threatening presence in the room.
'Intruder hallucinations' during sleep paralysis involve perceiving a dangerous presence, sometimes called 'sleep paralysis demons.'
Sleep paralysis occurs when REM atonia (muscle paralysis) persists into a state of wakefulness, creating a mixed state of consciousness.
People with obstructive sleep apnea have higher rates of sleep paralysis—38% in one study.
All mammals studied show signs of REM sleep, suggesting that mammals may dream like humans.
Giraffes sleep only about 4.6 hours per day, and their sleep cycles are just 35 minutes or shorter.
Elephants may sleep as little as 2 hours per day and can travel for nearly two days without sleeping.
Little brown bats sleep about 20 hours per day, some of which is spent in torpor.
Dogs spend over a third of their day asleep, with another 21% in drowsy relaxation.
Horses can sleep standing up during NREM sleep but must lie down for REM sleep due to muscle atonia.
Dolphins, eared seals, and manatees sleep unihemispherically—one brain hemisphere sleeps while the other stays awake.
Walruses can sleep for 19.4-20.5 hours per day on land, but can also go up to 84 hours without sleep while swimming.
Walruses can hook their tusks onto ice floes and sleep while hanging in the water.
Birds can sleep unihemispherically, with one eye closed corresponding to the sleeping hemisphere of the brain.
Mallard ducks at the edge of a flock sleep with one eye open watching for predators, while ducks in the middle sleep with both eyes closed.
Alpine swifts have been documented flying continuously for 200 days, likely sleeping unihemispherically while gliding.
Migratory white-crowned sparrows get only a third of their normal sleep during migration, compensating with micro-naps.
Bats and perching birds have locking tendons in their feet that allow them to sleep while hanging or perched without falling.
Bears can go up to 7 months without eating, drinking, urinating, or defecating during hibernation, though their body temperature stays nearly constant.
The Madagascan fat-tailed dwarf lemur is the only primate known to truly hibernate.
Reptiles like the Australian dragon (Pogona vitticeps) show sleep states similar to REM and NREM sleep.
Snakes sleep with both eyes open because they have no eyelids, and can sleep for days while digesting food.
Crocodiles can engage in unihemispheric sleep, keeping one eye open to watch for threats and prey.
Parrotfish secrete a cocoon of mucus around themselves for protection while they sleep.
Spanish hogfish and blue-headed wrasse can be lifted by hand to the surface without waking when in deep sleep.
Some sharks that breathe through ram ventilation (keeping their mouths open while swimming) may sleep one hemisphere at a time.
Fruit flies (Drosophila) sleep, and sleep deprivation in flies leads to cognitive disabilities similar to those in mammals.
Jumping spiders show REM-like sleep with regularly occurring bouts of retinal movements.
Octopuses have a two-staged sleep similar to REM and NREM, with color changes during 'active sleep.'
Sleep-like states have been observed in jellyfish (Cassiopea) and hydra, organisms without brains or central nervous systems.
Even sponges show evidence of sleep-like states, suggesting sleep may have evolved hundreds of millions of years ago.
In the nematode C. elegans, a lethargus sleep-like phase occurs before each molt, suggesting sleep is connected to development.
Salamanders can enter brumation (reptile hibernation) for up to 100 days at a time.
Green-striped burrowing frogs can enter estivation during dry periods, burrowing deep underground for months without moving or eating.
Sleep is a highly conserved behavior across animal evolution, likely originating hundreds of millions of years ago.
Brain cleansing, including removal of amyloid proteins, may be one of the original evolutionary purposes of sleep.
The fact that both birds and mammals have REM and NREM sleep suggests this trait evolved in their common amniote ancestors.
Early mammals engaged in polyphasic sleep (multiple sleep periods per day), with monophasic sleep evolving later in larger mammals.
No complex animal has been found that doesn't need sleep or doesn't suffer consequences from sleep deprivation.
Antti Revonsuo's threat simulation theory proposes that dreaming evolved to help humans practice dealing with dangers in a safe environment.
Time-based activity rhythms may be an ancient form of niche partitioning to minimize competition during certain parts of the day.
During slow-wave sleep, humans secrete bursts of growth hormone essential for tissue repair and growth.
All sleep, including daytime naps, is associated with the secretion of prolactin.
Sleep only reduces metabolism by about 5-10%, contradicting the theory that sleep's primary purpose is energy conservation.
Mammals need to return from hypothermia to normal body temperature to sleep during hibernation, actually costing energy.
Breathing becomes faster and irregular during REM sleep compared to the slower, regular breathing of NREM sleep.
The sensory threshold increases during sleep—sleeping people perceive fewer stimuli but can still respond to loud noises.
Polysomnography measures brain waves (EEG), eye movements (EOG), and muscle activity (EMG) to analyze sleep stages.
Male armadillos get erections during non-REM sleep, while the inverse is true in rats.
Sleep inertia—grogginess and impaired performance upon awakening—is more pronounced when waking from deep sleep stages.
People can reliably train themselves to wake up at a specific time without an alarm clock.
Hypnagogic hallucinations occur while falling asleep, while hypnopompic hallucinations occur while waking up.
False awakenings are vivid dreams of waking up that can repeat multiple times before actual awakening.
REM Sleep Behavior Disorder causes people to physically act out their dreams due to failure of normal muscle atonia.
Sexsomnia is a parasomnia involving sexual behavior during sleep that the person doesn't remember.
Sleep talking (somniloquy) can occur during any sleep stage and is usually harmless.
Night terrors typically occur during deep NREM sleep and are most common in children, who usually don't remember them.
Exploding head syndrome involves perceiving a loud bang or explosion when falling asleep or waking up, but isn't dangerous.
Sleep drunkenness (confusional arousals) involves severe confusion upon waking, sometimes lasting minutes to hours.
Sleepwalking occurs during deep NREM sleep and can involve complex behaviors like cooking or driving.
Some people have short sleeper syndrome, genetically needing only 4-6 hours of sleep without negative effects.
Kleine-Levin syndrome causes episodes of sleeping up to 20 hours per day for days or weeks at a time.
Bruxism (teeth grinding) during sleep affects about 8% of adults and can cause jaw pain and tooth damage.
Recurring dreams—the same or similar dreams repeating over time—are experienced by many people and may relate to unresolved stress.
Pre-sleep hallucinations (hypnagogic imagery) are common and include seeing patterns, faces, or geometric shapes as you fall asleep.
Artificial light has substantially altered humanity's sleep patterns compared to ancestral humans who slept with natural light cycles.
Blue light from smartphones and screens suppresses melatonin and is associated with circadian rhythm disruption.
Wearable sleep trackers and smartphone apps can collect data about movement, sounds, and heart rate during sleep.
Light therapy using a light box can help reset circadian rhythms for people with sleep phase disorders.
CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) machines are the most common and effective treatment for obstructive sleep apnea.
Humans are among the only animals that willingly delay sleep, often due to work, social activities, or entertainment.
The record for the longest period without sleep is about 11 days (264 hours), achieved by Randy Gardner in 1964.
Sleeping on your back increases the risk of sleep apnea and snoring due to gravity's effect on the airway.
The feeling of falling and jerking awake (hypnic jerk) is experienced by about 70% of people as they fall asleep.
12% of people dream entirely in black and white, though this was more common before color television.
Sleep quality tends to decrease with age due to deterioration of the medial prefrontal cortex affecting slow-wave production.
You cannot sneeze while sleeping because the muscles involved are relaxed during sleep.
Being awake for 18+ hours creates impairment equivalent to a blood alcohol level of 0.05%.
New parents lose an average of 6 months' worth of sleep in their child's first two years of life.
Regularly getting less than 6 hours of sleep increases mortality risk by 12%.
The body is almost entirely paralyzed during REM sleep, with only the eyes and breathing muscles active.
You forget 50% of your dream within 5 minutes of waking, and 90% within 10 minutes.
Sleeping too much (more than 9-10 hours regularly) is also associated with health problems including cardiovascular disease.
Sleep position affects dream content—people sleeping on their stomachs report more vivid and often erotic dreams.
The first sleep cycle of the night is typically the shortest, ranging from 70 to 100 minutes.
Later sleep cycles tend to be longer, between 90 and 120 minutes each.
The composition of each sleep cycle changes throughout the night, with more deep sleep early and more REM later.
During deep sleep (N3), brain waves slow to 1-4 Hz (delta waves), the slowest brain wave frequencies.
Deep sleep contributes to insightful thinking and creativity, even though brain activity is reduced.
Sleepers typically awaken soon after the end of a REM phase or sometimes in the middle of REM.
The ventrolateral preoptic nucleus (VLPO) is a key brain region that promotes sleep onset.
The ascending reticular activating system keeps us awake and is inhibited during sleep.
Glycogen depletion in the forebrain contributes to the homeostatic drive for sleep.
The left-brain interpreter creates a plausible narrative from signals received during sleep, which we experience as dreams.
Even in constant light or darkness, humans maintain rhythmic melatonin and body temperature cycles on a slightly longer than 24-hour period.
The suprachiasmatic nucleus shows conspicuous oscillation activity that intensifies during subjective day and drops to nearly nothing at night.
Non-24-hour sleep-wake rhythm disorder occurs when the internal clock fails to sync with the 24-hour day, causing sleep times to shift daily.
Advanced sleep-wake phase disorder causes people to feel sleepy very early in the evening and wake up extremely early.
Delayed sleep-wake phase disorder causes people to not feel ready for bed until very late at night and struggle with early wake times.
Exercise, meal timing, and social interactions serve as secondary zeitgebers that help regulate circadian rhythms.
Insufficient sleep syndrome is diagnosed when someone sleeps less than recommended most nights for at least three months.
A sign of sleep deprivation is sleeping much longer on weekends or days off than on regular days.
One night without sleep can temporarily increase blood pressure.
Animal studies suggest prolonged sleep deprivation can cause structural and potentially irreversible brain damage.
Sigmund Freud proposed that dreams serve to protect sleep by representing wishes as fulfilled to prevent awakening.
The activation-synthesis hypothesis proposes that dreams result from the brain trying to make sense of random neural activity during sleep.
Francis Crick's 'reverse learning' theory suggests dreams help remove parasitic neural connections and unnecessary information.
People often recognize faces in dreams even when the dream character's appearance is distorted.
Ancient Egyptians believed dreams were the best way to receive divine revelation and practiced dream incubation.
The defensive activation theory proposes that dreams evolved to keep the visual cortex busy during sleep's darkness.
Erik Hoel proposes that dreams prevent 'overfitting' to past experiences, enabling the brain to generalize learning.
In ancient Sumer, King Gudea rebuilt a temple based on instructions received in a dream around 2140 BCE.
The SSILD (Senses Initiated Lucid Dream) technique involves cycling through awareness of vision, hearing, and body sensations before sleep.
Reality testing for lucid dreaming includes trying to push a finger through your palm—if you can, you're dreaming.
Keeping a dream journal may help improve dream recall and facilitate lucid dreaming.
Lucid nightmares can occur where the dreamer is aware they're dreaming but unable to escape terrifying content.
The brain sorts through memories from the previous day during NREM sleep, filtering important from unimportant information.
During REM sleep, the thalamus transmits sensory cues to the cerebral cortex, where memories are interpreted and processed.
Cataplexy in narcolepsy can be triggered by strong emotions like laughter, surprise, or anger.
In children with narcolepsy, cataplexy often affects the face (appearing as a tic) rather than the whole body.
Many people with narcolepsy are not diagnosed until years after their first symptoms.
Narcolepsy onset peaks at around age 15 and again around age 35.
Restless legs syndrome can cause sleep disruption and is a risk factor for parasomnias.
Fatal familial insomnia is a rare prion disease that causes progressively worsening insomnia leading to death.
Obstructive sleep apnea is more common in men and people with higher body mass index.
High altitude increases the risk of central sleep apnea due to decreased oxygen availability.
Some antidepressants can increase the likelihood of parasomnias as a side effect.
Sleep paralysis can be ended by another person's touch or voice, or by intense effort to move.
First episodes of sleep paralysis often occur in childhood, adolescence, or young adulthood.
Vestibular-motor hallucinations during sleep paralysis can include sensations of flying or out-of-body experiences.
The only eyes that move during bird unihemispheric sleep are those connected to the awake hemisphere.
Nocturnal animals have higher body temperatures and serotonin levels at night—the inverse of diurnal animals.
Small species with higher metabolic rates may have less efficient sleep patterns than larger animals.
Birds exposed to predator risk have less deep sleep than birds in protected environments.
Cockroaches show a rest period characterized by folded antennae and decreased sensitivity to stimuli.
Crayfish show EEG changes during sleep that differ markedly from their awake patterns.
Cave-dwelling blind fish may not sleep due to the constant darkness eliminating circadian cues.
Zebrafish become motionless at night and float in place during their sleep period.
Sleep patterns in fish can disappear during migration, spawning, and parental care periods.
Awakening involves heightened electrical activation beginning with the thalamus and spreading throughout the cortex.
Women are awake for 0-1% of their nightly sleep, while men are awake for 0-2%.
Wakefulness increases in later sleep cycles, from 3% in the first cycle to 13-14% in the fifth.
Determinants of alertness after waking include sleep quality, prior physical activity, and breakfast composition.
Sleep eating disorder involves eating while asleep with no memory of it upon waking.
Sleep-related hallucinations are distinct from those in psychiatric conditions and usually resolve with improved sleep.
Somnambulistic homicide—killing someone while sleepwalking—has been used as a legal defense in some cases.
Sleep deprivation can paradoxically help prevent cluster headaches in people who suffer from them.
Hypoglossal nerve stimulation is an implanted device that moves the tongue forward during sleep to treat sleep apnea.
Transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS) delivering current to the frontal cortex may help induce lucid dreams.
China spans what would be five time zones but officially uses only one (UTC+8), affecting sleep patterns.
Scientists who discovered REM sleep in 1953 were Eugene Aserinsky and Nathaniel Kleitman.
A healthy entrained adult will naturally fall asleep a few hours after sunset and wake a few hours after sunrise.
The genes Per, tim, and Cry are 'clock genes' that influence circadian rhythms and sleep timing.
Polyphasic sleep (multiple sleep periods per day) is more common in animals than monophasic sleep.
Napping after 3 PM can interfere with nighttime sleep for most adults.
The optimal nap duration is 10-20 minutes to avoid sleep inertia.
Cooling the body before bed promotes sleep onset; core body temperature naturally drops during sleep.
Exercising too close to bedtime (within 1-2 hours) can interfere with falling asleep.
The amino acid tryptophan in food doesn't significantly affect sleepiness; it's a myth that turkey makes you sleepy.
Sleep debt cannot be fully repaid by weekend sleeping—chronic sleep loss has lasting effects.
Daylight saving time transitions are associated with increased heart attacks and car accidents.
Insomnia is different from sleep deprivation: insomnia involves difficulty sleeping despite adequate opportunity.
Hartmann's theory proposes that dreams serve a quasi-therapeutic function for processing trauma.
Social simulation theory suggests dreams evolved to help practice social skills and bonds.
Chronobiological mechanisms are found in microbes, suggesting biological rhythms predate sleep itself.
It's hypothesized that REM sleep evolved from short bouts of motor activity in reptilian ancestors.
Slow-wave sleep may have evolved from basking behavior in reptiles, which shows similar EEG patterns.
Marmosets can achieve monophasic sleep because they sleep in trees surrounded by protective family members.
Scientists can tell elephants are sleeping when their trunks stop moving.
Nurse sharks, which breathe by pumping water through their cheeks, can rest motionless on the seafloor.
Lizards may choose sleep perches with heads oriented toward predator approach paths for faster response.
During sleep, the body enters an anabolic state that helps restore immune, nervous, skeletal, and muscular systems.
REM stands for rapid eye movement, describing the distinctive eye movements during this sleep stage.
The term 'paradoxical sleep' refers to REM sleep because brain activity is high despite the body being paralyzed.
Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is considered more effective long-term than sleep medications.
Sleep disorders are estimated to be underdiagnosed, with many people living years with untreated conditions.
Thomas Edison slept only 4 hours a night and promoted the idea that sleep was a waste of time.
Leonardo da Vinci allegedly practiced polyphasic sleep with multiple 20-minute naps throughout the day.
Sleep-related painful erections are a rare disorder causing painful erections specifically during REM sleep.
Cataplexy is sometimes mistaken for seizures or fainting but involves maintained consciousness throughout.
Alpha waves (8-12 Hz) are seen when a person is relaxed but awake with eyes closed.
Gamma waves occur during highly focused concentration and have the highest frequencies of all brain waves.
Short pulses of light at the right moment can significantly 'reset' the internal circadian clock.
REM-like sleep has recently been found in fish, suggesting this sleep type evolved earlier than previously thought.
The Old English word 'drēam' originally meant 'noise,' 'joy,' or 'music'—not the sleep experience.
The word 'dream' for sleep-related imagery came from Old Norse 'draumr' in the 13th century.
Homeostasis drives the need for sleep—the longer you're awake, the stronger the sleep drive becomes.
1-5% of children have obstructive sleep apnea, much more common than central sleep apnea in young people.
Helium has the lowest boiling point of any element at -268.9°C, and remains liquid even at absolute zero under normal pressure.
The Kola Superdeep Borehole in Russia reaches 12,262 meters deep - the deepest artificial point on Earth, where temperatures reach 180°C.
The Challenger Deep in the Mariana Trench reaches 11,034 meters below sea level - the deepest known point in Earth's oceans.
Gold has a density of 19.32 g/cm³, so dense that a cubic foot would weigh over half a ton.
Lithium is the lightest metal with a density of just 0.534 g/cm³ - light enough to float on water.
Hydrogen is the lightest element with a density of just 0.08987 g/L at standard conditions.
GCIRS 13E is one of the most massive known stars at approximately 1,300 solar masses - so massive it defies current stellar models.
Light travels at exactly 299,792,458 meters per second - the cosmic speed limit that nothing with mass can reach.
Earth orbits the Sun at approximately 107,200 km/h (67,000 mph), completing one revolution every 365.25 days.
Mauna Kea in Hawaii rises 10,203 meters from its oceanic base - taller than Mount Everest when measured from base to peak.
Venus has a surface temperature of 464°C - hotter than Mercury despite being farther from the Sun, due to its runaway greenhouse effect.
Mercury's surface temperature swings from 700°C during the day to -180°C at night - the most extreme temperature variation in the solar system.
The Nile River stretches 6,650 km through northeastern Africa, making it the longest river in the world.
The Amazon River carries more water than any other river - about 20% of all freshwater flowing into the world's oceans.
Tantalum has the second highest melting point of any element at 3,017°C and is used in surgical implants because it's non-reactive in the body.
Mercury is the only metal that's liquid at room temperature, with a melting point of -38.83°C.
The Kuril-Kamchatka Trench plunges 10,542 meters deep, making it one of the deepest oceanic trenches in the world.
The Philippine Sea contains Bakunawa deep at 10,925 meters, making it one of the deepest points in the ocean.
Melnick 42 is a hypergiant star approximately 189 times the mass of our Sun, located in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
LBV 1806-20 is a luminous blue variable star approximately 165 solar masses - one of the most massive stars known.
Uranium has a density of 19.05 g/cm³, making it one of the densest naturally occurring elements.
Californium is so rare that only 8 grams have ever been produced, yet it has a density of 15.1 g/cm³.
Neon has a boiling point of -246°C and produces the iconic reddish-orange glow in neon signs.
Fluorine has an extremely low boiling point of -188°C and is the most electronegative element on the periodic table.
The Yangtze River stretches 6,300 km across China, making it the longest river in Asia and third longest in the world.
The Yellow River (Huang He) is 5,464 km long and carries so much sediment that it gives the water its distinctive yellow color.
The Atlantic Ocean reaches 8,605 meters at its deepest point in the Milwaukee Deep of the Puerto Rico Trench.
The Indian Ocean's deepest point is 7,450 meters in the Java Trench, yet it contains the warmest ocean waters.
The Southern Ocean reaches 7,235 meters deep and surrounds Antarctica with the coldest ocean water on Earth.
Earth maintains an average temperature of 15°C, making it the only planet known to support liquid water on its surface.
Mars experiences temperatures ranging from 35°C to -143°C, with an average of -63°C.
UY Scuti is one of the largest known stars, with a radius approximately 1,700 times that of our Sun.
Earendel is the most distant individual star ever detected, located approximately 12.9 billion light-years from Earth.
Molybdenum has a melting point of 2,623°C and is essential for high-strength steel alloys used in construction.
Hafnium has a melting point of 2,233°C and is used in nuclear reactor control rods due to its neutron-absorbing properties.
Iron has a melting point of 1,538°C and makes up about 32% of Earth's total mass, concentrated in its core.
Gold melts at 1,064°C and is so malleable that one ounce can be stretched into a wire 80 km long.
The Mississippi River flows 3,766 km through the heart of North America, draining about 40% of the continental United States.
The Volga River at 3,530 km is Europe's longest river and drains into the Caspian Sea.
The Mekong River stretches 4,350 km through six countries in Southeast Asia, feeding 60 million people.
The Congo River is 4,700 km long and is the deepest river in the world, reaching depths of 220 meters.
Rhodium is one of the rarest elements with a density of 12.41 g/cm³ and is more valuable than gold or platinum.
Carbon has two wildly different forms: graphite (one of the softest minerals) and diamond (the hardest natural substance).
Boron has one of the highest boiling points at 4,000°C and is harder than most steels.
Silicon has a boiling point of 2,570°C and makes up 27.7% of Earth's crust by mass, second only to oxygen.
The Mediterranean Sea reaches 5,267 meters at its deepest point in the Calypso Deep.
The Caribbean Sea plunges to 7,686 meters in the Cayman Trough - deeper than many oceanic trenches.
The Arctic Ocean's deepest point is 5,550 meters, yet it's the shallowest of the world's five oceans on average.
The Lockheed SR-71 Blackbird reached speeds of 3,530 km/h (Mach 3.3), making it the fastest air-breathing manned aircraft ever built.
NML Cygni is a red hypergiant star with a radius 1,642 times that of the Sun - if placed at the Sun's position, it would engulf Jupiter's orbit.
Rho Cassiopeiae is a yellow hypergiant star 40 times the mass of our Sun that pulses irregularly, changing brightness dramatically.
AG Carinae is a luminous blue variable star 55 times the mass of our Sun and one of the most luminous stars in the Milky Way.
Potassium is so light (0.862 g/cm³) that it floats on water, and so reactive it bursts into violet flames on contact.
Gallium melts at just 29.76°C - low enough that it will melt in your hand, yet boils at 2,204°C.
Oganesson (element 118) is the heaviest known element and exists for only milliseconds before decaying.
Scientists theorize elements up to atomic number 184 (unoctquadium) could exist in an 'island of stability' in the periodic table.
The Brahmaputra River flows 2,900 km and drops 4,500 meters from its source in Tibet to the Bay of Bengal.
The Indus River is 3,180 km long and gave India its name - 'Indus' comes from Sanskrit 'Sindhu' meaning river.
Mount Olympus in Greece rises 2,918 meters and was believed by ancient Greeks to be the home of the gods.
The Sulu Sea plunges to 5,576 meters and is nearly completely enclosed by islands in the Philippines.
The South China Sea reaches 5,559 meters deep and contains some of the world's busiest shipping lanes.
The Weddell Sea near Antarctica reaches 6,820 meters deep and produces some of the coldest, densest water in the world.
The Sargasso Sea reaches 7,000 meters deep and is the only sea without a coastline, bounded only by ocean currents.
Technetium was the first artificially produced element and has no stable isotopes - all its forms are radioactive.
Beryllium has an unusually high melting point (1,287°C) for such a light element and is transparent to X-rays.
Arsenic sublimes (turns directly from solid to gas) at 615°C without passing through a liquid phase at normal pressure.
Selenium has photoconductor properties - its electrical resistance decreases when light shines on it.
Antimony expands when it freezes (unlike most materials), a property it shares with water, gallium, and bismuth.
Tellurium is one of the rarest stable elements in Earth's crust, about three times rarer than gold.
Indium is so soft you can bite it, and it squeaks when bent - a property called 'tin cry'.
Astatine is the rarest naturally occurring element - at any given time, less than 30 grams exist on Earth.
The Lena River in Siberia is 4,294 km long and remains frozen for 7-8 months of the year.
The Yenisei River at 3,487 km is the largest river system flowing into the Arctic Ocean.
The Ob River in Russia is 3,650 km long and its basin contains some of the world's largest wetlands.
The Niger River flows 4,180 km through West Africa and uniquely curves away from the sea before turning back toward it.
Praseodymium gets its name from the Greek for 'green twin' due to its green salts, and is used in special aircraft metals.
Holmium has the highest magnetic moment of any element, making it useful in powerful magnets.
Zirconium has excellent corrosion resistance and is used in nuclear reactors because it doesn't absorb neutrons well.
Yttrium was discovered in 1794 and is named after Ytterby, a Swedish village that gave its name to four elements.
Scandium is lighter than titanium but has a higher melting point and is used in aerospace alloys.
Vanadium is named after Vanadis (Freyja), Norse goddess of beauty, due to the colorful compounds it forms.
Chromium's name comes from Greek 'chroma' (color) because it forms compounds in almost every color of the rainbow.
Manganese is essential for photosynthesis - without it, plants cannot split water molecules to release oxygen.
Cobalt gives the distinctive blue color to cobalt blue pigment, used in art for over 5,000 years.
Nickel is magnetic at room temperature - one of only four elements (with iron, cobalt, and gadolinium) with this property.
Copper has been used by humans for over 10,000 years and remains essential in electrical wiring due to its conductivity.
Zinc prevents iron from rusting through galvanization and is the fourth most common metal in use today.
Lead has been used for 6,000 years and was once added to gasoline, paint, and even food as a sweetener.
Tin has been alloyed with copper to make bronze since 3000 BCE, revolutionizing human civilization.
Silver has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of any element, making it ideal for electronics.
Cadmium is extremely toxic yet was used in yellow and red pigments by artists including Monet and Van Gogh.
Iodine sublimes at room temperature, producing beautiful purple vapors that were first observed in 1811.
Barium's compounds produce green flames in fireworks and were used in early television screens.
Calcium makes up 3.6% of Earth's crust and is essential for bones, teeth, and muscle contraction.
Magnesium burns with an intensely bright white flame that cannot be extinguished by water.
Sodium explodes on contact with water and must be stored under oil to prevent contact with air.
Aluminum was once more valuable than gold - Napoleon III served honored guests with aluminum cutlery while others used gold.
Titanium has an exceptional strength-to-weight ratio and is used in aircraft, spacecraft, and medical implants.
Argon makes up nearly 1% of Earth's atmosphere - the third most abundant gas after nitrogen and oxygen.
Nihonium (element 113) was the first element discovered in Asia, synthesized in Japan in 2004.
The Horizon Deep in the Tonga Trench reaches 10,817 meters - the second deepest point in the ocean after Challenger Deep.
The Greenland Sea reaches 5,600 meters deep and plays a crucial role in global ocean circulation.
The Banda Sea plunges to 6,400 meters and contains some of the richest marine biodiversity in the world.
The Celebes Sea reaches 6,200 meters deep and is nearly completely enclosed by the Philippine and Indonesian archipelagos.
Gravitational waves travel at exactly the speed of light (299,792,458 m/s), as predicted by Einstein in 1916.
Tachyons are hypothetical particles that would always travel faster than light - they cannot slow down to light speed.
The graviton is the hypothetical particle that mediates gravity - if it exists, it must be massless.

In the English language, many animals have different names depending on whether they are male, female, young, domesticated, or in groups.
The best-known source of many English words used for collective groupings of animals is The Book of Saint Albans, an essay on hunting published in 1486 and attributed to Juliana Berners.

It goes on to say that some of the terms in The Book of Saint Albans were "rather fanciful", explaining that the book extended collective nouns to people of specific professions, such as a "poverty" of pipers.
Some terms that were listed as commonly used were "herd", "flock", "school", and "swarm".
When he interviewed scientists who specialize in studying specific animals, they had not heard of these terms, such as a "bask" of crocodiles or "wisdom" of wombats, being applied in their fields.

Lund noted that the common plural nouns for animals were "flock" for birds and "herd" for cows, conceding that for certain animals in small groups, there was currency in usage such as a "pod" of whales or "gaggle" of geese.
This is a list of the longest-living biological organisms: the individuals or clones of a species with the longest natural maximum life spans.

For a given species, such a designation may include:

The oldest known individual(s) that are currently alive, with verified ages.
There are numerous plants and animals for which the mortality rate has been observed to actually decrease with age, for all or part of the life cycle.
The lifespan may be long or short, though the species technically does not "age" in the biological sense.
Individuals of other species have been observed to regress to a larval state and regrow into adults multiple times.
The hydrozoan species Turritopsis dohrnii (formerly Turritopsis nutricula) is capable of cycling from a mature adult stage to an immature polyp stage and back again.
Similarly, the larvae of skin beetles undergo a degree of "reversed development" when starved, and later grow back to the previously attained level of maturity.
Various claims have been made about reviving bacterial spores to active metabolism after millions of years of dormancy.

Spores preserved in amber have been revived after 40 million years, and spores from salt deposits in the Salado Formation of New Mexico have been revived after 250 million years, making these bacteria by far the longest-living organisms ever recorded.

Similarly, in May 2022 prokaryotic and eukaryotic microorganisms were found in crystals of halite; these could be over 800 million years old but it remains uncertain if they are alive or if they could be revived.
In a related find, a scientist was able to coax 34,000-year-old salt-captured bacteria to reproduce.

In July 2018, scientists from four Russian institutions collaborating with Princeton University reported that they had analyzed about 300 prehistoric nematode worms recovered from permafrost above the Arctic Circle in the Sakha Republic, and that after being thawed, two of the nematodes revived and began moving and eating.
These nematodes were believed to be the oldest living non-clonal multicellular organisms on Earth.
A seed from the previously extinct Judean date palm was revived and managed to sprout after nearly 2,000 years.
Similarly, the flowering plant Silene stenophylla was grown from frozen fruit found in an ancient squirrel's cache.
In 2024, a never-before-seen species of Commiphora was grown from a successfully germinated seed that is estimated to be 1,000 years old.

During the 1990s, Raul Cano, a microbiologist at California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo, US, reported reviving yeast trapped in amber for 25 million years, although doubts were raised as to its antiquity.
Cano founded a brewery and crafted an "amber ale" with a 45-million-year-old variant of Saccharomyces cerevisiae.
In August 2013, researchers reported evidence of endoliths in the ocean floor, perhaps millions of years old, with a generation time of 10,000 years.
Some Actinomycetota found in Siberia are estimated to be half a million years old.
A huge colony of the sea grass Posidonia oceanica in the Mediterranean Sea near Ibiza, Spain, is estimated to be between 12,000 and 200,000 years old.
The maximum age is theoretical, as the region it now occupies was dry land at some point between 10,000 and 80,000 years ago.
A Huon pine colony on Mount Read, Tasmania, is estimated at 10,000 years old, with individual specimens living over 3,000 years.
Discovered by Professor Leif Kullman of Umeå University, Old Tjikko is small, only 5 m (16 ft) in height.
"Humongous Fungus", an individual of the clonal subterranean fungal species Armillaria solidipes in Oregon's Malheur National Forest, is thought to be between 2,000 and 8,500 years old.
Apart from its extreme age, it is also thought to be the world's largest organism by area, at 2,384 acres (965 hectares).
A huge colony of the sea grass Posidonia australis in the Australian coast over Shark Bay is estimated to be over 4,500 years old and also the world's largest known plant.
It is therefore the oldest known living individual non-clonal tree in the world.
A specimen of Fitzroya cupressoides in Chile was measured by ring count as 3,654 years old, meaning this species has the second-oldest verified age of any non-clonal tree species.
The Cypress of Abarkuh, a Mediterranean cypress (Cupressus sempervirens) in Iran, is estimated to be between 4,000 and 5,000 years old.
The Llangernyw Yew, an ancient yew (Taxus baccata) in the churchyard of the village of Llangernyw in North Wales, is believed to be between 4,000 and 5,000 years old.
The President, located in Sequoia National Park, California, is the oldest known living giant sequoia (Sequoiadendron giganteum) at approximately 3,200 years of age.

A Panke baobab (Adansonia digitata) in Zimbabwe was some 2,450 years old when it died in 2011, making it the oldest angiosperm ever documented, and two other trees of the same species – Dorslandboom in Namibia and Glencoe in South Africa – were estimated to be approximately 2,000 years old.
It is the oldest known living human-planted tree in the world.
A specimen of Lagarostrobos franklinii in Tasmania is thought to be about 2,000 years old.
The Fortingall Yew, an ancient yew (Taxus baccata) in the churchyard of the village of Fortingall in Perthshire, Scotland, is one of the oldest known individual trees in Europe.
Various estimates have put its age between 2,000 and 5,000 years, although it is now believed to be at the lower end of this range.
Stara Maslina (Old Olive Tree) near Stari Bar in Montenegro, is estimated to be over 2,200 years old.
Tāne Mahuta, a kauri tree (Agathis australis) in New Zealand, is believed to be between 1,250 and 2,500 years old.
It is the oldest and largest standing kauri tree at present.
Old Tjikko, the world's oldest known Norway spruce in Sweden, continues via vegetative cloning.
Although its trunk may be only a few centuries old, its root system is estimated to be 9,568 years old.
Although this may be an overestimate, this is likely the longest lived animal on Earth.
Specimens of the black coral genus Leiopathes, such as Leiopathes glaberrima, are among the oldest continuously living organisms on the planet: around 4,265 years old.
The giant barrel sponge Xestospongia muta is one of the longest-lived animals, with the largest specimens in the Caribbean estimated to be more than 2,300 years old.
The Antarctic sponge Cinachyra antarctica has an extremely slow growth rate in the low temperatures of the Southern Ocean.
A specimen, "Ming" of the Icelandic cyprine Arctica islandica (also known as an ocean quahog), a mollusk, was found to have lived 507 years.
The tubeworm Escarpia laminata that lives in deep sea cold seeps regularly reaches the age of between 100 and 200 years, with some individuals determined to be more than 300 years old.
Some confirmed sources estimate bowhead whales to have lived at least 211 years of age, making them the oldest mammals.
Specimens of the Red Sea urchin Strongylocentrotus franciscanus have been found to be over 200 years old.
Geoduck, a species of saltwater clam native to the Puget Sound, have been known to live more than 160 years.
If correct, it would have been the world's oldest, having been hatched in 1859.
Orange roughy, also known as deep sea perch, can live up to 149 years.
George the lobster (an American lobster, Homarus americanus) was estimated to be about 140 years old by PETA in January 2009.
Tardigrades, capable of cryptobiosis, have been shown to survive nearly 120 years in a dry state.

An orca of the Southern Resident population identified as J2 or Granny was estimated by some researchers to have been approximately 105 years old at her death in 2017; however, other dating methods estimated her age as 65–80.
A lungfish named Methuselah was determined to be between 92 and 101 years old in 2023, making her the oldest living fish in captivity at the time.
Jeanne Calment, a French woman, lived to the age of 122 years and 164 days, making her the oldest fully documented human who has ever lived.
He holds the record for the oldest ever male human.
The oldest known person alive today is Ethel Caterham, a British woman, at age 116 years, 163 days (born 21 August 1909).
If confirmed, the tortoise would have been the oldest known terrestrial animal to have ever existed.
Jonathan, a Seychelles giant tortoise living on the island of Saint Helena, is reported to be at least 193 years old, hence the oldest currently living terrestrial animal.
If Adwaita's claim is not true, Jonathan might be the oldest known terrestrial animal to have ever existed.
Tu'i Malila, a radiated tortoise, died at the age of 188 in May 1966, at the time the oldest verified vertebrate.
The oldest known bird in the world was an Australian sulphur-crested cockatoo called Cocky Bennett, who lived to 120.
The tuatara, a lizard-like reptile native to New Zealand, can live well over 100 years.
Henry, a tuatara at the Southland Museum in New Zealand, mated for the first time at the estimated age of 111 years in 2009 with an 80-year-old female and fathered 11 baby tuatara.
She is believed to be the oldest elephant in captivity in Asia and was nicknamed Gaja Muthassi (grandmother of elephants).
Lin Wang, an Asian elephant, was the oldest elephant in the Taipei Zoo.
Henry, a Nile crocodile currently living in the Crocworld Conservation Centre of Scottburgh, South Africa is reported to be 123–124 years old, making him the oldest crocodile in captivity.
Muja, an American alligator at Belgrade Zoo, is considered the oldest alligator in the world.
Fatou, a gorilla at the Berlin Zoo is the oldest gorilla ever at the age of 68.
As of 2017, she is the oldest known wild bird in the world.
The oldest living horse on record, Ol' Billy, was allegedly born in the year 1760 in London, England.
Estimated to be 60 prior to his euthanasia, he may have been the oldest known individual of his species.
The oldest bear on record was Andreas, a European brown bear, living in the ARCTUROS bear sanctuary in northern Greece.
A wild-born black rhino named Elly was the oldest in North America at an estimated 45 years of age, and resided in California's San Francisco Zoo from April 1974 until passing in May 2017.
The oldest living spider, named Number 16 by researchers, was a 43-year-old female Gaius villosus armored trapdoor spider, at the North Bungulla Reserve, Tammin, Western Australia.
Debby, the polar bear, an inhabitant of the Assiniboine Park Zoo in Winnipeg, Canada, was the oldest polar bear and third-oldest bear species on record when she died in 2008, at the age of 42.
The oldest recorded bat, a Siberian bat (previously identified as a Brandt's bat), was at least 41 years old at the time of capture.
The oldest goat was McGinty who lived to the age of 22 years and 5 months until her death in November 2003 on Hayling Island, UK.

A mouse named Patrick Stewart (in tribute to the actor) has been verified by Guinness World Records as the oldest living mouse in human care as well as the oldest mouse ever, aged 9 years 210 days as of 9 February 2023.
The oldest gerbil was a Mongolian gerbil named Sahara, she was born in May 1973 and died on 4 October 1981 aged 8 years and 4 months.

Numerous animal species naturally produce chemical toxins which are used to kill or incapacitate prey or as a defense against predators.

Venomous animals actively deliver their toxins (called venom) into their target through a specially designed mechanism, such as a bite or sting, by using a venom apparatus, such as fangs or a stinger, in a processes called envenomation.

They are often distinguished from poisonous animals, which instead passively deliver their toxins (called poison) to their victims upon contact such as through inhalation, absorption through the skin, or after being ingested.
The only difference between venomous animals and poisonous animals is how they deliver the toxins.

Their intended effects can range from mild fleeting discomfort to paralysis and death, and they may be highly selective in which species they target, often making them harmless to all but a few specific organisms; what may be fatal to one species may be totally insignificant to another species.
Because the definition of "venomous" can be extremely broad, this list includes only those animals with venom that is known or suspected to be medically significant for humans or domestic animals.

For these animals, there is documented evidence of homosexual behavior of one or more of the following kinds: sex, courtship, affection, pair bonding, or parenting, as noted in researcher and author Bruce Bagemihl's 1999 book Biological Exuberance: Animal Homosexuality and Natural Diversity.
exhibit, stated "[M]any researchers have described homosexuality as something altogether different from sex.

They must realize that animals can have sex with who they will, when they will and without consideration to a researcher's ethical principles." Homosexual behavior is found amongst social birds and mammals, particularly the sea mammals and the primates.
In 1986, it was even discovered amongst insects when butterfly scientist W.J.
Sexual behavior takes many different forms, even within the same species and the motivations for and implications of their behaviors have yet to be fully understood.
Bagemihl's research shows that homosexual behavior, not necessarily sex, has been documented in about five hundred species as of 1999, ranging from primates to gut worms.

Homosexuality in animals is seen as controversial by social conservatives because it asserts the naturalness of homosexuality in humans, while others counter that it has no implications and is nonsensical to equate natural animal behaviors to morality.

The correct usage of the term homosexual is that an animal exhibits homosexual behavior, however this article conforms to the usage by modern research, applying the term homosexuality to all sexual behavior (copulation, genital stimulation, mating games and sexual display behavior) between animals of the same sex.

In October 2023, biologists reported studies of mammals (over 1,500 different species) that found same-sex behavior (not necessarily related to human orientation) may help improve social stability by reducing conflict within the groups studied.

While an uptick in research on bird homosexuality – and animal homosexuality in general – has been coming out in recent years, it is common for some authors to labour in articulating the view any root cause or function of bird homosexuality is poorly understood.

In 1977, The New York Times also reported on a colony of lesbian seagulls "off [the] coast of California."

While many eruptions only pose dangers to the immediately surrounding area, Earth's largest eruptions can have a major regional or even global impact, with some affecting the climate and contributing to mass extinctions.
An eruptive phase can consist of a single eruption, or a sequence of several eruptions spread over several days, weeks or months.

Despite their ostensibly benign appearance, effusive eruptions can be as dangerous as explosive ones: one of the largest effusive eruptions in history occurred in Iceland during the 1783–1784 eruption of Laki, which produced about 15 km3 (4 cu mi) of lava and killed one fifth of Iceland's population.
The ensuing disruptions to the climate may also have killed millions elsewhere.
These can comprise hundreds of large eruptions, producing millions of cubic kilometers of lava in total.
No large eruptions of flood basalts have occurred in human history, the most recent having occurred over 10 million years ago.
They are often associated with breakup of supercontinents such as Pangea in the geologic record, and may have contributed to a number of mass extinctions.
